title: 113_s1415
content: The Act is titled the "Canyon Mountain Land Conveyance Act of 2013" and includes definitions. The "Canyon Mountain Land Conveyance Act of 2013" defines "Federal land" as approximately 17,826 acres depicted on a specific map and "planning area" as land administered by the Bureau of Land Management in various districts. The "Canyon Mountain Land Conveyance Act of 2013" defines public domain land as areas in the Roseburg, Salem, and Klamath Falls Resource Area of the Lakeview District, excluding lands managed according to the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The "Canyon Mountain Land Conveyance Act of 2013" excludes land managed under the Act of August 28, 1937 and defines terms such as Secretary and Tribe. The "Canyon Mountain Land Conveyance Act of 2013" transfers Federal land to the Tribe, including minerals, to be held in trust by the United States. A survey to establish boundaries must be completed within 180 days. The "Canyon Mountain Land Conveyance Act of 2013" transfers Federal land to the Tribe, including minerals, to be held in trust by the United States. A survey to establish boundaries must be completed within 180 days. SEC. 4. MAP AND LEGAL DESCRIPTION. The Secretary must file a map and legal description of the Federal land with the Senate and House Committees. The filed map and legal description will have the same force and effect as if included in the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct any errors. The map and legal description filed under subsection (a) will be available for public inspection in the Office of the Secretary. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATION. Unless expressly provided in this Act, existing tribal rights to land are preserved. Federal laws on exporting unprocessed logs from Federal land apply, and land taken into trust cannot be used for gaming activities under Public Law 100-497. The Federal land must adhere to all applicable Federal laws for commercial forestry activities. Land reclassification is governed by specific regulations. The Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary must identify Oregon and California Railroad land to be conveyed under the Act within 180 days. Public domain land of similar acreage and condition within the planning area must be identified within 18 months. Maps must be provided within 2 years of the Act's enactment. After identifying the land, the Secretary will submit maps to Congress and the Federal Register within 2 years. The land will be reclassified as owned by the Oregon and California Railroad after public comment, with relevant laws applying to the reclassified land.
